title: Formal Script
content:
I need to print addresses on a friend's wedding invitations that were already printed with a return address. Any help would be appreciated.   
   
 ![Invitation](http://web.archive.org/web/20080415085423im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/34254.gif)

 [‹ (x) Pier Paolo Pasolini - Clarendon {Mark S, Metadox}](http://web.archive.org/web/20080415085423/http:/www.typophile.com/node/4444 "Go to previous forum topic") [Budweiser Font ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080415085423/http:/www.typophile.com/node/4456 "Go to next forum topic")
author: pmiura

comments.content: Now that I think about this, would the post office have trouble reading such an ornamental script? If this is the case, can anyone reccomend a complementary serif?

The font used for the script looks like [Citadel Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20080415085423/http:/www.fonts.com/findfonts/detail.asp?pid=203230). However, I agree that this would not be appropriate for addressing the envelopes. My suggestion would be to use a legible Italic face from a serif font, or else a formal serif font (preferably not Times ;-))

What about using a complementary sans that breathes   
a similar atmosphere, something like [Engravers' Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20080415085423/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/engravers-gothic/engravers-gothic/testdrive.html?s=75%20Gateshead%20Lane%20South&p=36)?

Thanks Mike, you script hound.   
   
Engravers' is nice. I was also looking at some high contrast extended faces. However, both ideas were nixed out. "They look like a business letter!" At the moment, they like [Snell](http://web.archive.org/web/20080415085423/http:/www.adobe.com/type/browser/F/SNLQ/F_SNLQ-10005000.jhtml).

... which is not very appropriate for addresses neither IMHO.   
Try to talk them out of these curly scripts, or you'll be one   
more victim of a postal drive-by shooting! This is serious!   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080415085423im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/bigsmile.gif)
You could also go with one of the Engravers fonts like AT Classic, or AT Burin. Both from Agfa.
